newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spanish bonds shrug off realism, bet on EMU.
newsitem.headline: Spanish bonds shrug off realism, bet on EMU.

text.p: Though central banks have begun to dampen the Spanish market's euphoria over European Monetary Union (EMU), experts still see convergence going forward due mainly to political considerations.
Only on Monday, Bank of Spain Governor Luis Angel Rojo, cautioned the country must persist in fiscal restructuring.
"We are still not inside (EMU) yet and a long way remains," said Rojo. "It is not clear that the whole world can get in. The country has to make bigger efforts to stabilize."

The Spanish bond market has enjoyed an impressive rally in recent months, buoyed by optimism over a restrictive 1997 budget that would put the country on course for joining the founders of monetary union in 1999.

But the market turned cautious last week amid strong signals from the Bundesbank that peripheral European countries like Spain and Italy have not yet fulfilled the Maastricht criteria for convergence.
Still many dealers are betting political considerations will lead the founders of EMU to opt for a wider group from the start rather than a strict interpretation of Maastricht.
"I think every day the two positions become clearer. On one side, the political one and on the other, the economic," said Juan Antonio Mielgo, economist at Bank of America in Madrid.
Despite improving Spanish economic data, such as a slimming CPI and a strict 1997 budget, official statements seems aimed at restoring doubts about a wide EMU from the start.
"It makes sense to me that Bundesbank and Bank of Spain advise some caution, something which could counterbalance dealers' optimism," said Xavier Segura, chief economist at Caja de Cataluna.
Analysts explained central banks are suggesting a certain degree of realism. Up to now, only Luxembourg could really pass the exam and enter EMU, they said.
"Spain, is not yet meeting virtually any of the Maastricht criteria," said Segura.
German investors fear EMU could be weakened by allowing in too many countries with volatile economies, analysts said.
"Germany seems really interested in a stability pact to keep all the economic variables under surveillance," said Segura.
But from a political point of view, very rigid economic criteria are less important. Politically, Europe should be able to present itself as a whole and unique country.
"Europe has a very big strength from a commercial point of view. Outside it should present itself in a homogeneous form," one analyst said.
For this reason, the market remains optimistic a political will toward a wider union will assert itself.

"The Bundesbank is recommending a more cautious approach, but people know this is its duty," said Mielgo. "It would have been much worse if any member of the (German) government would have said the same words."
